title: Project 3: Web Scraping and Visualization
text:
Overview
In this project, I scraped data from the web using Python and created visualizations to present insights.


Skills Demonstrated

Web Scraping
Data Cleaning
Data Visualization



Key Code Example

# Import Libraries
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Scrape sample data
url = "https://example.com"
html_content = "<html><body><table><tr><th>Item</th><th>Value</th></tr><tr><td>Apples</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>Oranges</td><td>15</td></tr></table></body></html>"
soup = BeautifulSoup(html_content, "html.parser")

# Parse table into DataFrame
table = soup.find("table")
rows = table.find_all("tr")
data = []
for row in rows[1:]:
    cols = row.find_all("td")
    data.append([col.text for col in cols])

df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=["Item", "Value"])
df["Value"] = df["Value"].astype(int)

# Show DataFrame
print(df)

# Visualization
plt.bar(df["Item"], df["Value"], color=["green", "orange"])
plt.title("Sample Scraped Data Visualization")
plt.xlabel("Item")
plt.ylabel("Value")
plt.grid(axis="y")
plt.show()

      Item  Value
0   Apples     10
1  Oranges     15

title: Project 1: Predicting Breakout Footballers with Machine Learning
text:
In this project, I built a machine learning pipeline to predict breakout football players—those expected to drastically improve their goals or assists in the coming season. This was done using real-world player statistics and advanced ML interpretability tools like SHAP.
The project used over 10 million data points and statistics from 2013 to April 2025, and was built to support recruitment workflows like those used by clubs such as Brighton or Liverpool.

title: Project: SQL Integration Example
text:
🧠 Overview
In this project, I demonstrate the use of SQL alongside Python using sqlite3 and pandas.
This integration allows for efficient data querying and analysis directly from relational databases.



🔍 Setup and SQL Queries
import sqlite3 import pandas as pd


Create an in-memory SQLite database
conn = sqlite3.connect(“:memory:”)


Create table
conn.execute(““” CREATE TABLE players ( id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, goals INTEGER, assists INTEGER ); “““)


Insert data
conn.executemany(“INSERT INTO players (name, goals, assists) VALUES (?, ?, ?);”, [ (‘Alice’, 10, 3), (‘Bob’, 7, 5), (‘Charlie’, 2, 8)])


Query players with more than 5 goals
df = pd.read_sql_query(“SELECT * FROM players WHERE goals > 5;”, conn) df

title: Project 2: Premier League Data Dashboard (Power BI)
text:
📊 Overview
This project features a dynamic Power BI dashboard built to visualize key insights from Premier League football data. It allows users to explore team performance, player metrics, and trends interactively using filters, slicers, and drilldowns.

⚽ Designed for analysts, coaches, or recruitment staff to explore stats visually — no coding required!



🛠️ Skills Demonstrated

Interactive dashboard design

Power BI DAX formulas and calculated fields

Data transformation using Power Query

Visual storytelling and UX layout principles

Dynamic filters, cards, and time slicers



📂 Dashboard Pages
The Power BI report includes: - 📈 Team Comparison View
- 🧍 Player Performance Breakdown
- 📅 Season-over-Season Trends
- ⚽ Goals & Assists Heatmap

Note: All visuals are interactive and filterable in real time.



💾 Download Report



Download PBIX




🖼️ Sample Dashboard (Placeholder)
You can upload a static screenshot of your dashboard if needed here later.

title: 🧠 Reflection
text:
## 🧠 Reflection
This portfolio journey helped me:

Apply data science principles to real projects
Learn Git/GitHub version control deeply
Gain web publishing experience with Quarto

### 💡 Key Lessons - Importance of visual design in communicating work - Iteration and polish matter more than perfection - Small bugs are part of the learning process!
